Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Designing Collaboration Networks to Optimize Collective Problem Solving

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how the structure of collaboration networks affects the success of collective problem solving. Although intuition would suggest that networks which support the efficient diffusion of information perform better as a collectivity, theoretical work has proposed an inverse relationship between network efficiency and success in problem solving. In other words, it posits that less efficient communication networks may promote more effective problem solving because people need to search independently for solutions to problems. The increased diversity of the information might improve the chances that the group will find a better solution before arriving at a consensus. Attempts to evaluate this theory empirically have been inconclusive due to limitations of their scale and design. Using novel online resources, both observational and experimental, this research studies the effects of network efficiency on collective problem solving within large empirical communication networks. This project has implications for enhancing collaboration networks in research and education, and for designing efficient team structures in science and industry.

This project will provide insight into how the structure of collaboration networks among scientific researchers can influence the rate and quality of innovation. It will identify the ways that distributed, online collaboration networks can be designed to provide policymakers and industry managers with new strategies for improving groups and for enhancing problem solving capacities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to test the theoretical idea that the structure of collaboration networks affects the success of collective problem solving, drawing on theoretical work from Lazer and Friedman (2007) and empirical work from Mason, Jones, and Goldstone (2008) and Mason and Watts (2011). More specifically, theoretical work has proposed an inverse relationship between network efficiency and success in problem solving. In other words, it posits that less efficient communication networks may promote more effective problem solving because people need to search independently for solutions to problems. This research investigates a general situation where individual problem-solvers are embedded in a team, and they face a decision between exploring new solutions, or exploiting existing solutions that others have come up with. The goal of this project was to gather novel online data, both observational and experimental, to study the effects of network efficiency on collective problem solving within large empirical communication networks. The observational study's results were supportive of the idea that the efficiency of the collaboration network could harm collective performance. The results from the experiment show that the efficiency of the collaboration network had a significant effect on the quality of collective innovation such that inefficient networks discovered better top solutions as compared to efficient networks. On average, inefficient networks found solutions that were 21% better than efficient networks. The cause of this better performance was due to the greater solution diversity in inefficient networks. 

This research has implications for the United States’ economic competitiveness. This research provides managers and grant agencies with information about how to restructure organizations for optimal problem solving in business, engineering, and design, and it has implications for the network of Research and Development collaboration within organizations. If network structure can be shown to offer significant improvements in the long-run, then investment in restructuring organizations may be warranted. In particular, this research about data science has implications for economic competitiveness, as the wealth of data available to companies can be leveraged to make increasingly accurate predictions using teams of data analysts connected in appropriate collaboration networks.
